qas.question: Under whose reign did the last major building works take place?
The principle facade of the East Front is made from what type of stone?
Which king preferred official entertaining and royal duties to lavish parties?
Who added and restored furniture to The Royal Collection?
Who was responsible for decorating The Blue Drawing Room?
The refaced facade was made from what type of stone?
Which king placed more emphasis on official entertaining and royal duties instead of lavish parties?
What collection did Queen Mary take an interest in by adding and restoring pieces?

answers.text: Royal Collection of furniture and art

qas.question: Who decorated the Blue Drawing Room?
Whose reign never had a major building works take place?
Which king avoided official entertaining and royal duties in favor of lavish parties?
Who removed and ruined furniture in The Royal Collection?
Who burned the Green Drawing Room?

context: The last major building work took place during the reign of <a0_0><b10_0>King George V<b10_0/><a0_0/> when, in 1913, <a5_0><b13_0>Sir Aston Webb<b13_0/><a5_0/> redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to resemble in part Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. This new, refaced principal façade (of <a1_0><a6_0>Portland stone<a6_0/><a1_0/>) was designed to be the backdrop to the Victoria Memorial, a large memorial statue of Queen Victoria, placed outside the main gates. <a2_0><a7_0><b11_0>George V<b11_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/>, who had succeeded Edward VII in 1910, had a more serious personality than his father; greater emphasis was now placed on official entertaining and royal duties than on lavish parties. He arranged a series of command performances featuring jazz musicians such as the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919) – the first jazz performance for a head of state, Sidney Bechet, and Louis Armstrong (1932), which earned the palace a nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival as one of the venues making the greatest contribution to jazz music in the United Kingdom. George V's wife <a3_0>Queen Mary<a3_0/> was a connoisseur of the arts, and took a keen interest in the <a8_0>Royal Collection of furniture and art<a8_0/>, both restoring and adding to it. <b12_0><b14_0>Queen Mary<b14_0/><b12_0/> also had many new fixtures and fittings installed, such as the pair of marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy, dating from 1810, which the Queen had installed in the ground floor Bow Room, the huge low room at the centre of the garden façade. <a4_0><a9_0>Queen Mary<a9_0/><a4_0/> was also responsible for the decoration of the Blue Drawing Room. This room, 69 feet (21 metres) long, previously known as the South Drawing Room, has a ceiling designed specially by Nash, coffered with huge gilt console brackets.
